elles Will Ring member Aiden Roberts finds his own voice on this whimsical, melodic and, yes, even faintly psychedelic new album of folk-infused songs. Nick Drake is an admitted reference point for Roberts, though the influence is perhaps more apparent in texture than actual sound. This was, after all, recorded in RobertsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ Sydney home Ã¢â‚¬â€œ itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s folk music baked with inner-city Australian sun. That said, songs like Barking Dog & Swallow occasionally bring to mind Joe BoydÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s more lush arrangements for Drake. There are acoustic-psych touches to the material, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s more subtly-toned than the widescreen Byrds vistas of his day-job band. Roberts is ultimately his own man Ã¢â‚¬â€œ while itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s inevitable parts of his record collection seep intoÃ¢â‚¬Â¦
Ã¢â‚¬Â¦the music, they never overwhelm the songs. You wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t find any blatant facsimiles of other artists here, not even of Belles. Instead, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll find a low-key selection of songs that Roberts delivers in an almost-reluctant voice Ã¢â‚¬â€œ in the wrong hands, this could sound indifferent and uncommitted, but RobertsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ hesitance sounds vulnerable and even a little bit haunted. It adds an interesting dynamic to what are essentially sun-kissed and, at times, even vibrant songs.
